formats.name: Standard
formats.summary: Rotating format with the most recent sets. Fast-paced, accessible competitive play.
formats.tips: Standard rotates each fall. Check the official banned list before major events. Great format for newer players.

formats.name: Modern
formats.summary: Non-rotating format from 8th Edition forward. High power level with diverse archetypes.
formats.tips: Modern has a high entry cost but cards hold value. Fetch lands and shock lands are format staples.

formats.name: Legacy
formats.summary: Eternal format with nearly all cards legal. Extremely powerful and skill-intensive.
formats.tips: Force of Will and Brainstorm define the format. Reserve List cards make some decks expensive.

formats.name: Vintage
formats.summary: The most powerful format. Nearly everything is legal, with Power Nine restricted.
formats.tips: Restricted means only 1 copy allowed. Many games are decided by turn 1-2. Proxy tournaments are common.

formats.name: Commander
formats.summary: Multiplayer format with 100-card singleton decks led by a legendary creature.
formats.special_rules: Choose a legendary creature as your commander. Your deck can only contain cards within your commander's color identity. Commanders start in a special command zone and can be cast from there (with increasing costs). Players start at 40 life. 21 commander damage from a single commander is lethal.
formats.tips: Social format - discuss power level with your playgroup. Rule 0 allows groups to customize banned list. Great for casual play and self-expression.

formats.name: Pioneer
formats.summary: Non-rotating format from Return to Ravnica forward. Bridge between Standard and Modern.
formats.legal_sets: All sets from Return to Ravnica (2012) forward
formats.tips: No fetch lands means different mana bases than Modern. Growing competitive scene with Regional Championships.

formats.name: Pauper
formats.summary: Budget-friendly format using only commons. Surprisingly deep and competitive.
formats.legal_sets: All cards printed at common rarity in any set
formats.tips: Very affordable entry point. Common-rarity printings from any set count, so some powerful old cards are legal.

formats.name: Historic
formats.summary: Digital-only format on MTG Arena. Pioneer-like with digital-only cards.
formats.legal_sets: All sets on MTG Arena plus Historic Anthologies
formats.tips: Arena-only format with unique digital cards. Includes rebalanced cards and conjure mechanics.

formats.name: Brawl
formats.summary: Commander variant on MTG Arena with Standard-legal cards.
formats.special_rules: 60-card singleton deck with a legendary creature or planeswalker as commander. Standard card pool. 25 starting life (30 in multiplayer).
formats.tips: Great way to play Commander-style games on Arena. Rotates with Standard.

formats.name: Limited (Draft)
formats.summary: Open booster packs and build a deck on the spot. Tests card evaluation skills.
formats.special_rules: Open 3 boosters, pick one card from each pack, pass the rest. Build a 40-card deck from your picks plus basic lands.
formats.tips: Prioritize removal and creatures. Curve matters - have plays at 2-4 mana. Signals from passed packs indicate open colors.

formats.name: Limited (Sealed)
formats.summary: Build a deck from 6 booster packs. Tests deck building and adaptation.
formats.special_rules: Open 6 boosters and build a 40-card deck from your pool plus basic lands.
formats.tips: Usually play 2 colors. Look for synergies and bombs. 17 lands is standard. Sideboarding between games is key.

formats.name: Oathbreaker
formats.summary: Commander variant with planeswalker commanders and signature spells.
formats.special_rules: 58-card singleton deck plus a planeswalker Oathbreaker and instant/sorcery Signature Spell in command zone. 20 starting life. Multiplayer focused.
formats.tips: Signature Spell must match Oathbreaker's color identity. Games tend to be faster than Commander.
